questions.text: Amputation is often not required in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A,B,D-Gas gangrene ,Buerger’s disease and Diabetic gangrene are absolute indications for amputation. Option C-Chronic osteomyelitis is a relative and a rare indication.

choices.text: Intermittent claudication is the pain on first step
Falsely elevated ABPI may be found in diabetics
Rest pain occurs due to ischemia of muscles and skin
ABPI does not change with exercise and rest.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding peripheral vascular disease
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In this question B & C both options are correct but B is best answer. A- intermittent claudication is pain at last step not first so it is false B- In diabetics due to wall rigidity and poor compliance ABPI may be falsy high . So this is right C- Ischemia of muscle causes pain (this statement is partly correct) D- excercise leads to Fall in ABPI (so this statement is false)

questions.text: Adson’s test is positive in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Adson's test is a provocative test which is done in order to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome. Cervical rib is a cause of thoracic outlet syndrome so adson's test helps in diagnosing or detecting the cervical rib.

questions.text: Maximum tourniquet time for the upper limb is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Excessive tourniquet time causes both local pressure and distal ischemic effects, with nerve damage and even compartment syndrome. Tourniquets should usually be let down after 1 hour unless close to the end of a procedure They can then be reinflated after 5-10min for a further hour. Tourniquet time for upper limb: 1 hour Maximum tourniquet time for upper limb: 2 hours.

choices.text: Veins and nerves are never involved

questions.text: Which one is not true regarding Buerger’s disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D is the answer as veins and nerves are commonly affected in patients of buerger's disease. In buerger's disease there is involvement of artery, veins and nerves. In Atherosclerosis there is involvement of only the arteries and no involvement of veins and nerves. Option A is correct as Buerger's Disease is more commonly affects men. Option B is correct as Buerger's disease mosty presents by 40 to 50 years of age. Atherosclerosis occurs by 6th to 7th decade. Option C is correct as smoking is a predisposing factor for the development of Buerger's Disease.

questions.text: All are true about intermittent claudication except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B is wrong as Pain of Intermittent claudication is not positional Option A is correct as in intermittent claudication pain most commonly occurs in calf muscle. Option C is correct as atherosclerosis is an important predisposing factor for intermittent claudication. Option D is correct as typical characteristic of intermittent claudication is that the pain is relieved by rest .

choices.text: Distal ischemia affecting the skin of the toes

questions.text: Lumbar sympathectomy is of value in the management of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B is correct as when you subject a patient to lumbar sympathectomy the blood flow is redistributed and the skin receives more blood as it was receiving before the procedure. This increased blood flow to to the skin will help in treating distal ischemia affecting the skin of the toes. Option A is wrong as presence of intermittent claudication is a contraindication for lumbar sympathectomy. The reason for this is when a person is subjected to lumbar sympathectomy the blood flow is redistributed and redirected from the deeper muscle tissue to superficial skin, this increases the symptoms of intermittent claudication as it increases the ischemia to the underlying muscles and so we do not do lumbar sympathectomy if the patient has intermittent claudication. Option C Lumbar sympathectomy has nothing to do with arteriovenous fistula. Treatment of small AV Fistula is embolization and Large AV Fistula is excision. Option D Lumbar Sympathectomy has role to play in the treatment of back pain. Back pain can be because of number of reasons and we should try to find out the cause of back pain and treat accordingly.

questions.text: Removal of L1 ganglion in sympathectomy results in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C is the answer in this question as sympathetic outflow from T12, L1 and L2 is required for the ejaculation and also required for maintaining the sphincter tone of the internal urinary sphincter. If one removes the L1 ganglion then patient lands up with retrograde ejaculation and can lead to Infertility. Option A is wrong and for erection we need parasympathetic outflow and if we perform lumbar sympathectomy it will not lead to impotence. Option B is wrong as lumbar sympathectomy of L1 ganglion has no effect on urinary retention. Option D that is causalgia is severe burning pain in a limb caused by injury to a peripheral nerve and it is not caused because of lumbar sympathectomy.

questions.text: An adult patient with leg pain and gangrene of toe. His ankle to brachial arterial pressure ratio would be less than ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ankle Brachial Pressure index (ABPI) is a ratio of systolic BP in Ankle measured as blood pressure in Dorsalis pedis artery or posterior tibial artery and Systolic BP in brachial artery. It is used to assess the severity of peripheral artery disease. ABPI normal value ranges from 1 to 1.2 ABPI 0.5 to 0.9 indicates intermittent claudication ABPI 0.1 to 0.4 indicates critical limb ischemia ABPI more than 1.2 indicates atherosclerosis in the underlying vessel wall.

questions.text: Features of acute ischemia of limb are all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The classic presentation of patients with acute ischemia of the extremities may be recalled by the ‘five P’s” : Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paresthesias, and Paralysis. A sudden and complete embolic occlusion may result in a cool, waxy-appearing white extremity with no signs of cutaneous blood flow.

questions.text: Which is not true about thoracic outlet syndrome :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Whenever there is a neurogenic thoracic outlet syndrome patients develop pain and paresthesia along inner aspect of forearm and hand. This is the distribution along C8 T1 nerve route that is ulnar nerve distribution. Patients also develop atrophy of hypothenar muscles. Option B. This is true as neurogenic features are most common. Option C. If first rib presence is the cause of thoracic outlet syndrome then resection of the first rib relieves the symptoms. Option D. Adson’s test is a provocative test which we use in thoracic outlet syndrome.

questions.text: A 38 year old male who is chronic smoker and has a history of uncontrolled hypertension came to the casualty with sudden onset extremely severe tearing chest pain radiating to back. There is unequal pulse in both the upper extremities and X-ray chest shows widened mediastinum. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dissecting aneurysm of the thoracic aorta occurs in the poorly controlled hypertension. The episode resembles an MI, with sudden onset of extremely severe, tearing chest pain that radiates to the back and migrates down shortly after its onset. There may be unequal pulses in the upper extremities, and chest x-ray shows a widened mediastinum. Definitive diagnosis should be sought by noninvasive means such as CTA or MRA, but TEE is useful as well. Option B. Myocardial infarction(MI) is a differential diagnosis of dissecting aortic aneurysm. ECG and cardiac enzymes should be done to rule out an MI. Option C. Pulmonary embolism (PE) typically occurs around postoperative day 7 in elderly and/or immobilized patients. The pain is pleuritic, sudden onset, and is accompanied by shortness of breath. The patient is anxious, diaphoretic, and tachycardic, with prominent distended veins in the neck and forehead (a low CVP virtually excludes the diagnosis) Option D. Acute pancreatitis should be suspected in the alcoholic who develops an “upper” acute abdomen. The classic picture has rapid onset for an inflammatory process (a few of hours), and the pain is constant, epigastric, radiating straight through to the back, with nausea, vomiting, and retching. Physical findings are relatively modest, but there may be vaguely localized discomfort in the epigastrium.

choices.text: Removal of embolus from the blood vessel

questions.text: What is the use of the catheter shown in the following figure ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Fogarty Catheter : Fogarty arterial embolectomy catheter is a device developed in 1961 by Dr. Thomas J. Fogarty catheter is used to remove fresh emboli in the arterial system. It consists of a hollow tube with an inflatable balloon attached to its tip. The catheter is inserted into the blood vessel through a clot. The balloon is then inflated to extract it from the vessel. It is available in different lengths and sizes, and is often colour coded by size. Because it is less invasive than ordinary surgery, it reduces the chance of postoperative complications.

choices.text: Pain in muscle at rest only
Pain in muscle on first step
Pain in muscle on exercise only
Pain in muscle on last step.

questions.text: Intermittent claudication is defined as :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Intermittent claudication is also known as vascular claudication, is a symptom that describes muscle pain on mild exertion (ache, cramp, numbness or sense of fatigue),classically in the calf muscle, which occurs during exercise, such as walking, and is relieved by a short period of rest. It is classically associated with early-stage peripheral artery disease, and can progress to critical limb ischemia unless treated or risk factors are modified. Option A. Rest pain is a feature of critical limb ischemia. Intermittent claudication is never present on first step. If pain is present on first step it is usually of Osteo-arthritis Neurogenic claudication varies with posture- More on standing erect but less on bending forward. Vascular claudication: Cramping pain after walking certain distance , usually one step lower than the block .

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Leriche syndrome ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Leriche syndrome, is a form of central artery disease involving the blockage of the abdominal aorta as it transitions into the common iliac arteries. Classically, it is described in male patients as a triad of the following signs and symptoms: 1. claudication of the buttocks and thighs 2. absent or decreased femoral pulses 3. erectile dysfunction This combination is known as Leriche syndrome.However, any number of symptoms may present, depending on the distribution and severity of the disease, such as muscle atrophy, slow wound healing in the legs, and critical limb ischemia.

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient who is chronic smoker presented with a long history of intermittent claudication and blackish discolouration of toes. What is the preferred treatment ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) As in this patient dry gangrene has already developed we have to undertake the amputation of this toe as it won't get better with any of the treatment options available. Options A,B and C:- They should be considered for the underlying peripheral artery disease but not for the gangrene.

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient who is a chronic smoker came to hospital with history of pain on walking. You advised an angiography whose image has been shown to you. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) n this angiography we typically see corkscrew collaterals which is a characteristic finding in Buerger's disease . Option B. Atherosclerosis usually present at around 6th or 7th decade and involves large vessels. Option C. Leirch Syndrome involves aortoiliac vessels and not the medium sized vessels

questions.text: Raynaud’s syndrome occurs in all except ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Causes of Raynaud's Syndrome :

choices.text: Exposure to cold exacerbates the symptoms
if it is due to connective tissue disorder it is called raynaud"s disease

questions.text: All are true about raynaud’s phenomenon except ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Raynaud's phenomenon, is a medical condition in which spasm of arteries cause episodes of reduced blood flow.Typically, the fingers, and less commonly the toes, are involved.Rarely, the nose, ears, or lips are affected The episodes result in the affected part turning white and then blue.Often, numbness or pain occurs. As blood flow returns, the area turns red and burns. The episodes typically last minutes, but can last several hours. Episodes are often triggered by cold or emotional stress The two main types are primary Raynaud's, when the cause is unknown, and secondary Raynaud's, which occurs as a result of another condition. Secondary Raynaud's can occur due to a connective-tissue disorder, such as scleroderma or lupus, injuries to the hands, prolonged vibration, smoking, thyroid problems, and certain medications, such as birth control pills. Diagnosis is typically based on the symptom Raynaud disease is idiopathic.

questions.text: Reimplantation time for lower limb is upto ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Reimplantation time for extremities is 4 to 6 hours Reimplantation time for digits is 8 hours. Organ should be kept in bag which is placed in a contained filled with saline and ice.

questions.text: Commonest type of AV Fistula is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) There are 3 types of AV Fistula : A) Traumatic B) Iatrogenic - This is the most common type of AV fistula .Done in Renal Dialysis- Also known as Cimino Fistula ( Between Radial artery and cephalic vein) C) Congenital -1) Beckwith - Wiedemann Syndrome 2) Sturge Weber syndrome 3) Park -weber syndrome

questions.text: AV fistula can safely be ligated if the following is positive ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Allen test is a medical sign used in physical examination of arterial blood flow to the hands. Allen test, one hand is examined at a time: 1. The hand is elevated and the patient is asked to clench their fist for about 30 seconds. 2. Pressure is applied over the ulnar and the radial arteries so as to occlude both of them. 3. Still elevated, the hand is then opened. It should appear blanched (pallor may be observed at the finger nails). 4. Ulnar pressure is released while radial pressure is maintained, and the colour should return within 5 to 15 seconds. If color returns as described, Allen's test is considered to be normal. If color fails to return, the test is considered abnormal and it suggests that the ulnar artery supply to the hand is not sufficient. This indicates that it may not be safe to cannulate or needle the radial artery. Option B. Adson’s test is a provocative test used to diagnose Thoracic Outlet Syndrome. Options C and D. Trendelenburg test and Schwartz test is used for varicose vein.

questions.text: Most common site of peripheral aneurysm is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Most common site of peripheral artery aneurysm is : Popliteal artery Most common site of visceral artery aneurysm is : Splenic artery Most common cause of aneurysm in the body is : Berry aneurysm Most common site of extracranial aneurysm in the body is : Abdominal aorta

questions.text: Most common cause of Pseudoaneurysm is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Most common cause of pseudoaneurysm is : Trauma Option A. Most common cause of true aneurysm is : Atherosclerosis Option C: Congenital defects like marfan’s syndrome can lead to aneurysm but that is a true aneurysm Option D. Aneurysms caused by infection are called as mycotic aneurysm

questions.text: Most common part of subclavian artery to be affected by stenosis is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most common part of subclavian artery to be affected by stenosis is : First part. When there is stenosis of the first part of subclavian artery patients suffer from subclavian steal syndrome.

choices.text: Reversal of blood flow in the ipsilateral vertebral artery
Reversal of blood flow in the contralateral carotid artery
Reversal of blood flow in the contralateral vertebral artery
Bilateral reversal of the flow in the vertebral arteries

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true regarding subclavian steal syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Subclavian steal syndrome (SSS), also called subclavian steal phenomenon or subclavian steal steno-occlusive disease, is a constellation of signs and symptoms that arise from retrograde (reversed) blood flow in the vertebral artery or the internal thoracic artery, due to a proximal stenosis (narrowing) and/or occlusion of the subclavian artery. The arm may be supplied by blood flowing in a retrograde direction down the vertebral artery at the expense of the vertebrobasilar circulation. This is called the subclavian steal. It is more severe than typical vertebrobasilar insufficiency.

questions.text: Best graft for femoropopliteal bypass?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) For Suprainguinal graft - M/C graft is Dacron For Infrainguinal graft - Best graft material is Reverse saphenous vein graft and Best synthetic material is PTFE ( Polytetrafluoroethylene) First image is of DACRON graft and 2nd image is of PTFE graft .

questions.text: Which of the following agents is not a temporary embolization agents ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Temporary embolic agents include absorbable gelatin sponge,thrombin, gelfoam sponge powder, starch microspheres, oxidised cellulose and collagen fibre preparations. The FDA approved onyx (Ethynyl-Vinyl alcohol copolymer) in 2005 for the treatment of AV malformations. It is classified as a liquid, non adhesive non absorbable, permanent embolic agent that can be used for small and large vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best management for radiation induced occlusive disease of carotid artery ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is a surgical procedure used to reduce the risk of stroke from carotid artery stenosis (narrowing the internal carotid artery). In endarterectomy, the surgeon opens the artery and removes the plaque. The plaque forms and enlarges in the inner layer of the artery, or endothelium, hence the name of the procedure which simply means removal of the endothelium of the artery. An alternative procedure is carotid stenting, which can also reduce the risk of stroke for some patients.

questions.text: The size at which elective surgery is indicated in abdominal aortic aneurysm:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Indications of repair of Abdominal aortic aneurysm:- 1.Diameter 5.5 cm or more in men 2.Symptomatic aneurysm 3.For women and patients with greater than average rupture risk, AAA diameter 4.5 to 5.0 cm 4.Rate of expansion >1 cm/year 5.Atypical aneurysms (dissecting, pseudoaneurysm, mycotic, saccular and penetrating ulcer) regardless of size. Critical diameter: A) For abdominal aortic aneurysm : 5.5 cm B) For Ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm: 5.5 cm , and if 0.5cm/year it is indication for surgery C) For Descending thoracic aortic aneurysm: 6cm , if 1cm /year it is indication for surgery D) In marfan patients -thoracic aortic aneurysm 4.5-5 cm is the critical diameter.

questions.text: Classification System which is used for intra abdominal aortic aneurysm ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Classification system for intra abdominal aortic aneurysm is modified crawford classification. Most common site of intra abdominal aortic aneurysm is infrarenal abdominal aorta.

questions.text: Which of the following test used for thoracic outlet syndrome is also known as Scalene test ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of surgery for thoracic outlet syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Brachial plexus injuries, vascular injuries, pleural effusion, winged scapula, and infection are complications that may arise secondary to first rib removal. Complications of Thoracic Outlet Syndrome Surgery 1. Brachial plexus injuries 2. Winged scapula due to long thoracic nerve injury 3. Horner’s syndrome ? Vascular injuries (subclavian vessels) 4. Pleural effusion 5.Pneumothorax 6. Air embolism 7. Infection

questions.text: A 50-years-old male presented in the emergency with high BP (160/100) and heart rate of 120. A CECT is done which is given below. What is the next step in management.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The given image shows Aortic dissection involving the Ascending aorta with sparing of descending aorta [hence,It is Debakey Type II] First step of Management in aortic dissection is to Control the heart rate by short acting beta blocker like esmolol. [HR Goal The definitive management includes:- Type 1 & Type 2 debakey - Surgical repair using Dacron graft replacement. Type 3 - Conservative management There is no role of vitamin K inhibiots and heparin in management of aortic dissection.

questions.text: Most common artery involved in pseudoaneurysm:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In pseudoaneurysm all the layers are not involved, outer layer is intact and will be holding the blood Most common site of pseudoaneurysm-Femoral artery Most common site of central aneurysm-aorta Most common site of peripheral aneurysm-Popliteal artery Most common site of visceral aneurysm-splenic artery overall Most common aneurysm in body-berry aneurysm,present in circle of willis in Brain.

questions.text: Which of the following test is performed before taking sample for ABG analysis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A,C,D-Roos test,Adson’s test and Wright test are done for thoracic outlet syndrome. Option B-Allens test → Done to see integrity of palmar arch → to see both ulnar and radial artery working before taking ABG.

questions.text: In the given image, which clinical test is shown:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The given image shows Roos test.In this test, the patient abducts and externally rotates their shoulders with the elbow at a ninety-degree angle. The patient will then open and close their hand. Fatigue or reproduction of symptoms is a positive result. Option B,D-Wright test is also known as Costoclavicular test. Option C-Adson test is also done for thoracic outlet syndrome.

questions.text: Male smoker came with gangrenous ulcer on toe of left foot. He is complaining of early fatigue in right lower limb too while walking. Investigation for the diagnosis would be?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) PERIPHERAL VASCULAR DISEASE IS THE DIAGNOSIS in this case. Option A-Duplex scan is the IOC in peripheral vascular disease. Option B-Digital subtraction MRI is not the 1st line investigation as it is not easily available. Option C-CT angiogram is also not the 1st line investigation as there is risk of radiation. Option D-MR angiogram is not the 1st line investigation as it is not easily available.

questions.text: A man presented with a hematoma over the arm region and a history of stab injury. Radial and ulnar pulses are not felt. A 3.5cm longitudinal tear is noted in the brachial artery. Which of the following is the best treatment option?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-In this, big tear of brachial artery, primary repair will not be done as there are chances of stenotic narrowing. Option B-Repair with prosthetic graft is not commonly done as we've autologous graft like saphenous vein. Option C-Autologous reverse saphenous graft can be used to bypass/ repair that area. Option D-Repair with saphenous vein patch is not done.we've to reverse the saphenous vein graft and then put it,as there are valves present in vein.

choices.text: Pain on intermittent claudication comes at the first step of walking
Rest pain is seen in the night
The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about claudication pain?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Pain on intermittent claudication does not come at the first step of walking, but after walking a certain distance called the maximum claudication distance. Pain on the first step of walking is seen in osteoarthritis. Option B-Rest pain is seen in the night due to ischemia to nerves. Option C-Most common cause of claudication pain is atheroma . Option D-The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction in intermittent claudication.
